description.narrative: Although property violations are the most widespread form of abuse committed by armed actors against civilians in the DR Congo, they have received quite scanty attention both in research and policy. This research project aims to analyze the organization and effects of property violations committed by the state security services on small-scale economic actors in the DRC. The project is situated in the wider academic debate on security-development nexuses and will provide two types of data: 1) quantitative data on the levels and impact of property violations through surveys, and 2) qualitative data addressing: a) the organization of such violations, b) strategies of coping with and instrumentalizing security staff by small-scale economic actors, and c) factors which influence security staff propensities to engage in property violations.
